channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for AL
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for AL

item.title: Report X-2024051509
item.description:
Report X-2024051509

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-29T15:13:06+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-24
  • City: BESSEMER
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Federal Express Corporation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Fiberboard box containing 2 plastic jugs. One of the jugs had a noticeably loose cap during inspection, which led to liquid contents leaking out during handling. The box absorbed and contained the majority of the spill. The little liquid that did spill onto the dock was covered in neutralizing absorbent powder. Box and both jugs have been soiled/contaminated.

item.title: Report E-2024050596
item.description:
Report E-2024050596

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-27T21:12:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-17
  • City: BIRMINGHAM
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On May 17, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN2920 was damaged due to a load strap failure and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services, Inc. (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel overpacked the damaged drum in one (1) 55-gallon drum. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to further remediate the trailer. All impacted materials were contained in the same one (1) 55-gallon drum.
